questions.explanation: Correct Option A.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with 15 days of cough. On examination, cervical lymphadenopathy was noted, and the lymph node biopsy showed the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Type of Granuloma

Examples

Caseating Granuloma

Tuberculosis, Histoplasmosis, Coccidioidomycosis, Syphilis

Non-caseating Granuloma

Sarcoidosis, Crohn’s disease, Leprosy

Foreign Body Granuloma

Silicosis, Asbestos-related diseases, Foreign body reactions

Immune Granuloma

Wegener’s granulomatosis, Giant cell arteritis

Durck’s Granuloma

Cerebral malaria

Stellate Granuloma

Cat scratch disease

questions.text: Arrange the following cellular events of inflammation in the correct sequence: Rolling Cytokine-mediated integrin activation Adhesion Migration
During wound healing, the cells that appear first, due to chemotaxis, at the site of the wound are:
questions.explanation:
Events in wound healing

Day 0

Platelets and Fibrin form blood clots.

Day 1

Blood clot remains and recruitment of neutrophils (acute inflammation).

Day 2

Blood clots remain; neutrophils accumulate, followed by the formation of a thin epithelial layer.

Day 3

Chronic inflammation sets in, and macrophages replace neutrophils.

Granulation tissue begins (blood vessel formation starts)

Day 5
  • Maximum granulation tissue (Maximum neovascularisation)
  • Collagen bridging starts

Day 21(3rd Week)

Maximum collagen deposition (Type I collagen.)

Primary intention

Secondary intention

Primary intention healing involves rapid closure of a clean, surgically closed wound with minimal tissue loss, resulting in a small scar.

E.g., Surgical scar.

Secondary intention healing occurs when a wound is left open to granulate and epithelialise, often resulting in a larger scar and longer healing time.

Associated with wound contraction. e.g., Road traffic accidents.

questions.text: Match the cytokines with the effector cells IL-4 Eosinophils IL-5 b. Mast cells IL-9 c. B cells IL-13 d. Dendritic cells
questions.explanation:
Cytokine

Effector Cell

IL-4

B cells

IL-5

Eosinophils

IL-9

Mast cells

IL-13

Dendritic cells

Interleukin (IL)

Function

IL-1

Promotes fever and inflammation and activates T cells and macrophages.

IL-2

Stimulates growth and activation of T cells, critical for adaptive immunity.

IL-3

Supports growth and differentiation of hematopoietic cells (blood cell precursors).

IL-4

Stimulates B cell differentiation and promotes IgE production and Th2 response.

IL-5

Stimulates eosinophil differentiation and activation.

IL-6

Induces fever and acute-phase reactant production and supports B cell differentiation.

IL-7

Essential for T and B cell development and survival.

IL-8 (CXCL8)

Attracts neutrophils to sites of infection (chemotaxis).

IL-9

Promotes mast cell growth and regulates Th2 responses.

IL-10

Anti-inflammatory; inhibits Th1 responses and macrophage activity.

IL-12

Stimulates Th1 cell differentiation and enhances cytotoxic activity of T and NK cells.

IL-13

Modulates immune responses and activates macrophages.

IL-17

Promotes inflammation and recruitment of neutrophils, which are involved in autoimmunity.

IL-21

Stimulates B cell differentiation, plasma cell generation, and Th17 response.

IL-22

Induces antimicrobial peptide production and supports tissue repair.

IL-23

Promotes Th17 differentiation and inflammatory responses.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective enzyme in Acute inflammation?
questions.explanation:
Acute Inflammation

Chronic Inflammation

Causative agent

Pathogen, injured tissues

Persistent acute inflammation due to non-degradable pathogens, persistent foreign bodies, or autoimmune reactions

Cells infiltrated

Neutrophils/Polymorphonuclear cells (PMN).

Exception: Typhoid (Relative Lymphocytosis)

Lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma cells

Exception: Chronic

Pseudomonas (it shows the persistence of Neutrophils)

Primary mediators

Vasoactive amines, eicosanoids

IFN-y and other cytokines, growth factors, reactive oxygen species, hydrolytic enzymes

Onset

Immediate.

Delayed.

Duration

Few days.

Up to many months or years.

Outcomes

Resolution, abscess formation, chronic inflammation.

Tissue destruction, fibrosis.

questions.text: All of the following are growth-promoting proto-oncogenes, except?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - TGF-β

Growth Factor

Sources

Functions

Fibroblast growth factors (FGFs) including acidic (FGF-1) and basic (FGF-2)

Macrophages, mast cells, endothelial cells, many other cell types

Attracts and stimulates fibroblasts; promotes angiogenesis and ECM protein synthesis

Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)

Platelets, macrophages, endothelial cells, smooth muscle cells, keratinocytes

Attracts neutrophils, macrophages, fibroblasts, and smooth muscle cells; activates and stimulates fibroblast and endothelial cell proliferation; stimulates extracellular matrix (ECM) protein synthesis

Transforming growth factor-α (TGF-α)

Activated macrophages, keratinocytes, many other cells

Stimulates proliferation of hepatocytes and various epithelial cells

Transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β)

Platelets, T lymphocytes, macrophages, endothelial cells, epithelial cells, smooth muscle cells, fibroblasts

Attracts leukocytes and fibroblasts; stimulates ECM protein synthesis; suppresses acute inflammation

questions.explanation: Correct Option A - I

questions.text: Match the following: 1. Howell-Jolly bodies A. Ig inclusions 2. Dohle bodies B. Azurophilic granules 3. Flame cells C. Nuclear material remnants 4. Auer rod cells D. Remnants of ER
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B:

1. Howell-Jolly bodies C. Nuclear material remnants
2. Dohle bodies D. Remnants of ER
3. Flame cells A. Ig inclusions
4. Auer rod cells B. Azurophilic granules

Howell-Jolly bodies
  • Howell-Jolly bodies are small, round nuclear remnants found in red blood cells.
Dohle bodies
  • Dohle bodies are blue-grey cytoplasmic inclusions found in the white blood cells, particularly neutrophils.
  • They appear as small, irregularly shaped granules or vacuoles in the cytoplasm.
Flame cells
  • Flame cells, also known as urothelial cells, are specialized cells found in the renal tubules of the kidney.
  • They have a distinct appearance with a central nucleus and numerous hair-like extensions (cilia) that resemble a flame.
Auer rod cells
  • Auer rod cells are abnormal, rod-shaped structures that can be observed in the cytoplasm of myeloid precursor cells, particularly in acute myeloid leukemia.
  • These rod-like structures consist of fused granules of primary granules found in the cytoplasm of leukemic blast cells.

questions.text: An acute inflammatory response is not seen in which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - A

  Mechanism
Pyroptosis
  • Activation of inflammatory caspases
  • Formation of inflammasome complexes
  • Release of pro-inflammatory cytokines and DAMPs
  • Induction of cell swelling, membrane rupture, and lysis
Necroptosis
  • Activation of receptor-interacting protein kinases (RIPKs)
  • Formation of necrosome complexes
  • Release of pro-inflammatory cytokines and DAMPs
Apoptosis
  • Activation of caspases
  • Cellular condensation and fragmentation
  • Formation of apoptotic bodies
  • Recognition and phagocytosis of apoptotic cells
Necrosis
  • Cellular injury or damage
  • Disruption of cellular membranes
  • Release of intracellular contents and DAMPs
  • Induction of an acute inflammatory response
  • Recruitment of immune cells, such as neutrophils and macrophages
